1)Achieved. 2)Exceeded. 3)Achieved. 4)Not Achieved. Rakhine State Government representatives used quantitative and disaggregated data to analyze the development context and identify priorities for its 5-year development plan; however use of data is not regular and systematic yet. 5)Not Achieved. Combination of top-down and bottom-up processes: Rakhine State Government representatives at all levels (State, District, and Township) contributed to the formulation of the draft 5-year development plan. State level officials set vision and directions of the plan. District level officials coordinated between the State level and Township level officials. Township level officials conducted community consultations in all townships and provided feedback to the State 5-yeaer plan. Balancing of quantitative and qualitative information: Rakhine State Government used both statistical data and inputs from the experts as well as community consultations. Target setting informed by pilots: No. UNDP is currently supporting the Rakhine State Government to identify successful cases that could be piloted and could inform the target setting. 6)Exceeded

- New Government refines or redefines the framework and establishes mechanisms for monitoring - Medium-High (administrative coordination structures seek and incorporate inputs from multiple stakeholders outside of government, namely civil society organizations, academia and the private sector) - 2 pilot public administration reform initiatives supported - 2 learning opportunities or south-south cooperation opportunities - Adapted training curricula matching required skill set developed - Introductory course on Democratic Governance introduced, 1 targeted curricula for either mid-level or entry-level civil servants introduced based on needs assessment; Advanced Computer Training introduced; Basic Computer Training continues; Executive Management Course continues.

- The Government of Myanmar endorsed the NSFAR in early 2016 unanimously during a Cabinet meeting. With the change in government in April 2016, UNDP engaged with the UCSB to devise a Strategic Action plan to guide the modernization of the civil service. This Action Plan will be informed by the policy directives that were identified in the NSFAR, and also by a perception survey that was undertaken by UNDP on ethics, meritocracy and equal opportunities in the Service. This new policy document on Civil Service Reform is expected to enable the Government to promote integrity, meritocracy and accountability accross the civil service. The new government re-initiated consultation processes in order to ensure full participation of the stakeholders in the policy development process. - The UCSB has held consultations with and sought inputs from multiple stakeholders outside of government, namely civil society organisations, academia and the private sector, as well as region and state actors and representatives from other government institutions. The drafting task force for the CSR Action Plan is USCB internal, but the body charged with steering and monitoring its implementation has not been constituted yet. - The President Office started work on introducing an institutional performance management but this was not retained as part of the new administration's agenda. The UCSB started work on examining ways to improve individual performance management systems in the civil service. Minor improvements were introduced, but an overall revamp of the system is still in progress. - At the CSR workshop, the International Consultants participated and gave presentations as part of south-south cooperation. The International Consultants were from New Zealand, Mongolia, Korea. UNDP Experts from Singapore and Bangkok gave presentations as well. - Executive and Senior Management Trainings were provided at the two Central Institutes of Civil Service. United Nations Institute for Training

- Government uses reform framework to guide and monitor administrative reforms - High (Administrative coordination structures involve multiple stakeholders- CSOs, academia and private sector- in their deliberations and include them in the structures as full-fledged members) - 2 pilot public administration reform initiatives supported - 2 learning opportunities or south-south cooperation opportunities - Significant improvement in the capacity of pilot region and state institutions in terms of institutional structures, revised procedures and improved skills and knowledge - Skills of targeted top level civil servants in place - Introductory course on Democratic Governance introduced, 1 targeted curricula for either mid-level or entry-level civil servants introduced based on needs assessment; Advanced Computer Training introduced; Basic Computer Training continues; Executive Management Course continues.

- The CSR Strategic Action Plan was finalized and was presented to the general public on social media platforms for comments. It received largely positive feedback and support as a means to enhance efficiency of the administration, but also to address corruption issues. CSR strategic action plan was formally launched on 10 July 2017 by the State Counsellor in the presence of the highest level of political leadership in the country. The Civil Service Reform has replaced Administrative Reform in terms of policy priority for the current Government. Public Perception Survey of Government Services is also underway and scheduled to be completed in 2018. - The CSR Action Plan was drafted and finalised with through highly consultative approach and included multiple stakeholders. the plan includes also the establishment of a Steering Committee to implement and monitor the activiites. This Committee includes a sub-committee for States and Regions.the Committees have yet to be approved by the President Office. - Competency-based job description toolkit has been drafted. Anti-Corruption White Paper is submitted to the government with recommendations to have more coordinated approach in tackling corruption in Myanmar. - For south-south cooperation, the UNDP Global Center for Public Service Excellence (GCPSE) also launched the Global Study on Intrinsic Motivation in Developing Countries and organized a two-day knowledge forum on the 11 and 12 July 2017 to disseminate knowledge and engage Myanmar, ASEAN and global practitioners and scholars, in discussions around the issues of motivation, integrity, meritocracy and equal opportunity in support of civil service transformation. Myanmar will be among the first countries in the world to engage in the Global Study on Intrinsic Motivation, which is led by UNDP GCPSE, among other countries from various regions around the world. The study will inform the implementation of Myanmars CSR Strategic Action Plan and constitutes the first

Myanmar Hluttaw The Myanmar Hluttaw hosted and organized a major international event for the first time. The ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly (AIPA) General Assembly was organized in NPT at the end of September and early October. In preparation of this event the Myanmar Hluttaw had asked UNDP to provide training for the staff in order to manage to organize such an event. A range of trainings related to both skills and capacity were purposefully designed and delivered through the Learning Centre. The AIPA GA was successfully organized and the staff received high praise from the AIPA Secretariat. The training and the experience of the event further strengthened the capacity and confidence of staff in providing high level services to the Hluttaw and MPs. As a result the event also helped improve the confidence between the staff and the Parliament leadership and MPs.
Following up on the Committee Leadership and Development programme, which was organized in June, a seminar series on a range of policy issues were initiated. The seminar series is delivered in collaboration with different UN agencies, international organizations and NGOs, but the seminar also stresses the importance of incorporating national counterparts into the seminar. This has allowed for greater focus on the current situation related to each policy area in Myanmar and connected national stakeholders closer with the Hluttaw.
The capacities and resources to provide training, and the Learning Centre capacity in general, continue to improve. 16 organizations are now using the Learning Centre on a regular basis and several other organizations are providing one time workshops there. At the same time the institutional capacity for supporting the organization of the Learning Centre continues to be weak.
Upon completing the installation of the data centre it has now been possible to start working on developing ICT platforms and tools which will allow the staff and MPs to move towards an e-Parliament. T

description.narrative: This output project aims to promote rule of law and incresing people's access to justice, building capacities for coordinated justice sector reform and increasing legal awareness.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Project implementation office

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

- 3.1 Number of mid-level officials from justice institutions (the Supreme Court and Attorney Generals Office) trained to develop and deliver training programs to meet the needs of justice sector reform. - 3.2 Number of university law departments that include clinical legal education in their curricula. - 3.3 Percentage of trainees (in both justice institutions and law departments) reporting the relevance of training for practical use. - 3.4 Number of actions taken by justice institutions to promote consultative and participatory legislative development. - 3.5 Use of new approaches to raise legal awareness of vulnerable groups in targeted areas. - 3.6 Number of examples in which justice sector actors have responded to the priority justice needs of vulnerable people (e.g. action in specific cases or development of protocols/strategies) - 3.7 Number of justice sector policies/plans initiated to improve coordination on crosscutting justice concerns. - 3.8 Justice sector institutional capacity development plans produced and steps toward implementation undertaken

comment.narrative: - 3.1 None there was no system for training of trainers (TOT) - 3.2 No university law department in Myanmar has a clinic legal education in its curricula. - 3.3 Justice sector actors have expressed the need for knowledge and skill based-training. - 3.4 There have been no consultative and legislative participatory developments; legal drafting is closed. - 3.5 There are no special measures designed to increase legal awareness of vulnerable groups. - 3.6 Mapping study (December 2013) documents provide few examples in which justice sector actors have responded to priority needs of vulnerable people (e.g. in land registration disputes or cases of SGBV). - 3.7 None. There are no justice sector policies/plans which promote coordination on crosscutting justice concerns. - 3.8 No existing capacity development plans for justice sector actors (initial milestones to be identified once capacity development plans developed).

3.1 Fifteen mid-level officials from justice institutions trained to develop and deliver training programs to meet the needs of justice sector reform, through five mentoring sessions to support (i) curriculum development on fair trail principles and (ii) teaching skills. 3.2 Six university law departments include clinical legal education in their curricula 3.3 70% of justice actors trained by UNDP and law departments reporting relevance of training for practical use. 3.4 Three actions taken by justice institutions to promote consultative and participatory legislative development 3.5 One or more of the following approaches utilized to raise legal awareness of vulnerable groups in targeted areas: mobile clinics, multiple reinforcement, small-group training, and community-based support groups; and at least totaling six times per target area per year. 3.6 Four examples of justice sector actor responses the priority justice needs of vulnerable people (e.g. action in specific cases or development of protocols/strategies) 3.7 One policy/plan initiated to improve coordination on crosscutting justice concerns 3.8 Implementation of two justice sector institutional capacity development plans

3.1 36 justice officials completed training of trainers courses in fair trial topics and principles. UAGO 16 (7 males, 9 female), OSCU 20 (6 males, 14 female). State and regional training provided insights into trainees level of skills and knowledge for development of improved training curriculum for 2017. - 3.2 17 universities applied clinical legal education teaching modalities and principles during the 2015 -2016 academic year. CLE elements include community teaching, externship programs and mock trials. - 3.3 100% of 482 justice officials trained report that training in fair trials and rule of law topics is relevant to their work and requested further training. 100% of 7 law teachers trained are able to prepare CLE lessons plans and provide input to curriculum development and revision. 86% of 323 lawyers, CSO representatives and law teachers trained in 13 foundational rule of law courses, and four practical legal skills workshops reported high levels of satisfaction and knowledge gain. 100% of 27 UAGO officials and 100% of 13 OSCU officials trained in M&E report relevant of training for their practical use. - 3.4 1 OSCU led consultation on implementation of legal aid law. UAGO reviewed legislative handbook, requested changes and commits to new methods and systems for developing policy and laws. OSCU and UAGO held consultations on institutional policies to govern behavior of justice officials. OSCU held participatory 2nd High Level Dialogue on code of ethics for judges and judicial staff. UAGO also held participatory consultations on code of ethics for law officers at Union, states and regions. - 3.5 6 mobile trainings held in remote areas to raise legal awareness in remote areas, attended by 130 community leaders including village administrators, religious leaders, teachers, local health workers and farmers in Kachin and Shan States. Justice concerns highlighted include squatters and land issues, gender equality and gender-based violence, child protection

3.1 Twenty mid-level officials from justice institutions trained, through at least five mentoring sessions organized to support (i) curriculum development on fair trial principles and (ii) teaching skills. 3.2 Eight university law departments include clinical legal education in their curricula. 3.3 80% of justice actors trained by UNDP and law departments reporting improvement in their skills. 3.4 Four consultations with justice sector institutions. 3.5 One or more of the following approaches utilized: mobile clinics, multiple reinforcement, small group training, and community-based support group, and at least six times per target area per year 3.6 Four examples of justice sector actor responses. 3.7 One policy/plan initiated. 3.8 The implementation of justice sector institutional capacity development plans reviewed

3.1 604 justice officials, including 227 women, trained in Shan, Rakhine, Kachin and Yangon, by UNDP on rule of law, human rights, SGBV and fair trial standards. This includes first batch and refresher training for 297 judges, 214 law officers and 93 court support staff. Additional 120 officials will be trained in December in Mon and Kayin. The ROLCs have developed and piloted the following new Specialised Legal Courses: Gender and Substantive Equality Training; SGBV Training; Legal Ethics and Client-Centred Lawyering for legal aid service providers; Rule of Law Training for law officers; and Rule of Law Training for township administrators. - 3.2 ROLCs, together with BABSEACLE and Myitkyina University initiated a CLE externship program for university students of the law faculty (NB: This indicator and target is not relevant anymore since the activity has been completed in early January and has been removed from the 2017 work-plan during the mid-year revision). - 3.3 Three pilot specialised trainings for 62 law officers and 72 township administrators delivered with an 84% participation satisfaction rate. The ROLCs national survey of 196 training graduates conducted in June 2017 (a 32% response rate out of 600 graduates) reported increased skills and knowledge and demonstrated high impact: 95% of respondents indicated they have increased knowledge of the law and their rights; 94.5% indicated an increased ability to access, or to help others to access, judicial and administrative remedies; 91% indicated that the ROLC training courses changed their attitude to, and practice of, law; and 95% confirmed they use what they learned in ROLCs training in their work. - 3.4 Court Reporting and Consultation with Stakeholders in Myanmar Justice Sector for Judiciary Strategic Plan (2018-2022) was conducted by the OSCU. The third dialogue on the development of the code of ethics held by the OSCU to pave the way for the adoption of the judicial code of ethics in August 2017. OS

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: 1 Water diversion canal constructed 300 HH trained on SWC activities 23.4 ha of tree planting activities on public land 209 Ha of homestead gardening/agro-forestry plots established and 200 Ha of farm boundary plantations 570 HH (510 farmer plus 60 Staff) are trained on climate-resilient farming methods (Primary target) 20 Rice thresher and 120 multi-crop thresher provided 140 thresher groups establishment 1400 Persons received training event on transferring technical know-how climate resilient livestock practices from Livestock Department Officer to community members 500 HH has increased diversity of livestock assets 2 ToT training organized on CBDRM One Agro-meteorological bulletin produced

1 Shwebo Township Irrigation System renovation was completed to improve access irrigation and drinking water supply in Shwebo townships. 488 households (385 in project village and 103 in non-project village) will increase access to water for the agriculture purpose who are stayed in water scarce area and Shwebo city residents will access to safe water during flood and raining seasons. Total 152 HH (140 farmers represented from 140 project villages and 12 government staff) are trained on soil and water conservation to store fresh water and reduce accelerated runoff and erosion, slowing down surface water so it will penetrate the soil better and increase sub-surface storage. After the project, trained persons will remain in the area as resource persons for land degradation control. Activities on 23 ha of public land tree plantation and 200 ha of farm boundary plantation completed. 203 ha of Homestead gardening activities completed under establishment of agroforestry in the Dry Zone. 20 Rice Threshers and 107 Multi-crops threshers were delivered to the respective township DoA compounds. 27 Livestock Breeding and Veterinary Department staff had been trained on Climate-resilient livestock rearing and practices, then those trained staff had transferred community-level training to 5558 landless and farmers to improve fodder preparation and storage, rangeland management, disease control methods, fodder bank, livestock shelter practices and livestock banking system. 2 Training of Trainers (ToT) event on the Community Based Disaster Risk Management was conducted and 43 relevant government staff from 5 project townships participated the training. These officials will be able to provide an integrated capacity building package to the communities in at least 70 villages in next year when the formation of CBDRM in these villages will be rolled out. Developed five customized monthly forecast for the projects townships to enhance the quality of climate risk information.

- 20 water diversion canal constructed - 70 small scale water pumping systems installed - 56 communal water tanks installed - 40 shallow tube well and 10 deep tube well renovated or constructed - 75 communal ponds rehabilitated or constructed - 578 ha of land covered with soil and water conservation techniques - 150 person received training on soil & water conservation - 3,065 Ha of micro-watersheds are protected through natural forest conservation, community forest establishment and public land tree planting activities - 1,136 Ha of private and public land covered by community-based agroforestry plots and 650 Ha of farm boundary plantations - 7,725 HH receive training on climate-resilient farming methods - 9,240 HH participate in post-harvesting processing and storage in order to reduce climate-induced post-harvest losses - 3,000 HH has increased diversity of livestock assets - Conducted vulnerability assessment in 5 townships - Developed Climate Hazard mapping for 5 target townships - Produce 4 Agro-meteorological bulletins - 30 CBDRM committees are formed

44 run off/flash water diversion canals were renovated - which is more than the annual target for 2017 (20 diversion canals). Runoff water from upper catchment or existing natural waterway is collected and diverted into village ponds where villages can access drinking water, water for domestic use and for irrigation. 75 water retention ponds were renovated - which have increased water availability during the dry periods mainly for drinking and domestic use. soil and water conservation trainings were imparted to 152 HH (140 farmers represented from 140 project villages and 12 government staff) in 2017 and altogether with 2016, all 280 villages representatives in the project townships received soil and water conservation training and soil and water conservation measures were applied on 852 ha of land in the 5 project townships. While trying to obtain land approval, completed plantation in 2,624 ha of natural forest conservation area, 843 ha of community forest establishment, 325 ha of micro watershed management and 192 ha of public land. In addition, community based agroforestry plot such as homestead gardening, modified taungya crops and demo plots have been established on 465 Ha of land and farm boundary plantations on 510 ha have been completed during the reporting period. Promoted climate-resilient farming practices through a range of climate-resilient farming methods - alternate wet & dry technology (AWD), establishment of perennial trees (Thanakha and fruit trees), farmer managed seed multiplication, participatory demonstration plots, participatory varietal selection and farmers field school, which have benefited 1437 HH and 351 DOA staff in 5 project townships who shared these practices to 7365 HH in 2017. 9380 HH and 139 DoA staff participated in post-harvesting processing and storage activities in order to reduce climate-induce post-harvest losses and 722 farmers have been disseminated by the trained farmers. To introduce community-managed crop ha

- 70 small scale water pumping systems installed - 56 communal water tanks installed - 20 shallow tube well and 12 deep tube well renovated or constructed - 60 communal ponds rehabilitated or constructed - 304 ha of land covered with soil and water conservation measures - 1,086 Ha of micro-watersheds protected through natural forest conservation, community forest establishment and public land tree planting activities - Community-based agro-forestry plots established on 1,477 hectares of private and communal lands to conserve soil and water - 4,665 HH are trained on climate-resilient farming methods - 127 thresher user groups have been trained on resilient post-harvest processing and 36 elevated storage system installed in order to reduce climate-induce post-harvest losses - 1400 HH received climate resilient livestock production training - 1800 HH has increased diversity of livestock assets -Climate profiles and hazard maps (floods, earthquake and drought) for 5 townships updated and distributed to local government and related departments - 75 community based disaster risk management (CBDRM) team are formed to relay climate related early waring information - 75 village disaster management plan formulated to reduce risk and prepare communities during extreme events - 5 Climate risk information sub-committees established in targeted townships for effective communication of climate risk and early warning information - 5 ago-advisories per township/month issued to provide early warning to farmers and adapt to extreme weather events - Exit strategy and sustainability strategy/plan, including handover of activities for all project components prepared and implemented

To development a road map for enhancing the instutional capacity of the Nature and Wildlife Convservaiton Division

The road map to build the capacity of staff of Nature and Wildlife Conservation Division (NWCD) was drafted. The capacity of NWCD staff will be assessed using global registry for competency for staff of protected areas. Regular training for law enforcement and biological monitoring have been provided to staff of NWCD, WCS and community guardians. Under regular training program (1) 143 Forest Department staff were trained for Law Enforcement and SMART application, (2) 52 Forest Department and WCS staff were trained for Biodiversity Monitoring (3) 50 Community Guardian were trained to participate in PA management
To transform the current Forest School vocational training to a full diploma course

In September 2017, Project Board approved support to the Training and Research Development Division (TRDD) for the transformation of the Myanmar Forest School (MFS) 9-month vocational training to a 2-year diploma course. Associated costs include international technical assistance, training of trainers activities, capacity development initiative to enhance the skills and knowledge of trainers, support to the development of curriculum and teaching materials for the diploma course
